channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-7948] client doesn't need to refresh meta while the region is opening
item.summary: client doesn't need to refresh meta while the region is opening

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Part of HBASE-7649 patch, rebased.
Created a subclass of HRegionLocation with cache-specific fields, also moved seqNum there.
When the region is opening, server throws an exception similar to RegionMovedException; client handles it by not invalidating cache. There's a timeout on the latter behavior.

It will be more important combined with the rest of HBASE-7649 (see discussion there; basically retries will be improved when going to different server, so we don't want to quickly go to a different server, get "region not served" and go to meta).

Overall looks good. Some comments:

  • We probably don't want the conf/log4j.properties (and the other one under hbase-server/src/test) change for TRACE logging.
  • not sure why this import is there in hbase-client/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/exceptions/NotServingRegionException.java
    +import org.apache.hadoop.ipc.RemoteException;
  • I think if we cache RS that it is OPENING, and RS fails to do so, we will go to RS again, then get a NotServingException, and refetch meta again, right. Just asking to confirm that we do not have to wait the grace period.
  • Since RS only updates meta with location after it opens the region, this is only useful when combined with RegionMovedException's, right?

+1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12571108/HBASE-7948-v0.patch
against trunk revision .

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

+1 tests included. The patch appears to include 21 new or modified tests.

+1 hadoop2.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 2.0 profile.

+1 javadoc. The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

+1 findbugs. The patch does not introduce any new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 lineLengths. The patch does not introduce lines longer than 100

+1 core tests. The patch passed unit tests in .

We probably don't want the conf/log4j.properties (and the other one under hbase-server/src/test) change for TRACE logging.

It's commented out; I think it's a good idea to have it there as reference with comment, to be able to quickly enable it for debugging.

I think if we cache RS that it is OPENING, and RS fails to do so, we will go to RS again, then get a NotServingException, and refetch meta again, right. Just asking to confirm that we do not have to wait the grace period.

Yeah.

Since RS only updates meta with location after it opens the region, this is only useful when combined with RegionMovedException's, right?

Yes.
Woops, now it's no longer commented out, let me change

org.apache.hadoop.hbase.regionserver.TestSplitTransactionOnCluster

Console output: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/4589//console

This message is automatically generated.
Both tests pass locally, I don't think they are related. Enis Soztutar Nicolas Liochon do you guys want to take a look?

Lookinh at it right now.
This is unrelated?
-1 findbugs. The patch appears to cause Findbugs (version 1.3.9) to fail.

I like the idea. The coding is clean.
Actually, I'm not a big fan of the cache timeout. I think we have an history to not trust the assignment, and it burnt us in the past (double assignment caused by the time out manager for example). In this specific patch it's less risky, and it won't break the system, but I think we should trust the region server. It says it's opening the region, then we wait for it. If the region server is buggy, we should fix the root issue (we're risking data corruption here), and if it is just slow, there may be a root cause for that, and not adding any workload to meta seems better in this situation.

Hmm... perhaps we should set timeout higher? It seems dangerous to trust region server forever, then any buggy region server will be able to make region unreachable for the client.
I will look at findbugs.

Updating timeout, also some feedback from original JIRA.
There's no findbugs report in latest testResults, I will take a look after this one is picked up.

Console output: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/4652//console

This message is automatically generated.

In this case, it's more the fact that the pattern could be reused in more dangerous parts that worries me. And removing the timeout management makes the code much simpler. As usual, I'm not totally against the idea, just that I think that not having timeout management is better on both short term (less code) and long term (no risk to have a pattern reused in more dangerous places). If we don't trust the region server, I personally prefer to have a watchdog to kill it when it enters into an illegal state than to push this to the client code.

Can you please elaborate about more dangerous parts?
In my experience it's not safe to trust anything forever as a general principle, not because I think RS code is unreliable.
Even hardware itself is not reliable. Something as simple can happen as coincidence of RS bug and watchdog bug. Maybe RS will go into some crazy state where noone can reach it except client. Perhaps someone was debugging and killed some threads or whatever, so now RS won't die and behaves abnormally.
If master/RS cannot trust itself it may assert/halt/shut down, to prevent data loss.
But for client there's no data loss potential from flushing the cache, but there's potential to be stuck forever in case of abnormal RS behavior. With remote things I prefer to be defensive on all sides if practical

Can you please elaborate about more dangerous parts?

I was thinking about the code that we're slowly removing with HBASE-8002. It has 3 sides effects:
1) It was decreasing the performances, it has been fixed in numerous patches, but there are still scary comments and issues (HBASE-7247)
2) It was hiding issues. In the tests we had very low timeout, so master failover scenarios seemed to be working. In production, we were depending on a 10 minutes timeout but we didn't know.
3) It was causing double assignment issues, i.e. data corruption.

This was exactly the same logic (don't trust the RS), with more dramatic consequences.

In my experience it's not safe to trust anything forever as a general principle, not because I think RS code is unreliable.

I'm not against this, but in this case we need to tackle this the standard way: watchdog the process, and exclude the fuzzy ones from the group. Before doing this, I could like to see the chaos monkey test working with kill -9 for a while (I doubt it does today )
But I agree with your point, and we will have this soon or later (BTW, it's exactly why there are checksums in hdfs: because you can't trust the storage).

But for client there's no data loss potential from flushing the cache, but there's potential to be stuck forever in case of abnormal RS behavior. With remote things I prefer to be defensive on all sides if practical

Yeah. I'm likely biased. So, imho

  • the patch is an improvement. HBase is better with this patch than without.
  • it would be simpler without the RS-trust part
  • to me, at the margin on degraded conditions, it would be more efficient without the RS-trust part as well.

As we need to make progress , I propose:
1) Well, if you're not against the idea of removing the RS-trust part, we're done
2) If you really want to keep it, let's wait a few days if someone wants to come by. If no one does, let's commit on Friday.

What do you think?

Hmm... What you are saying makes sense.
Not sure really what is the choice here. Hardcoded long (10m?) timeout? So that it couldn't be configured to low value for tests. But that may not be good.
I am not adamant about keeping the timeout. Maybe I can change it to warning (no cache delete) on long hardcoded timeout, since we don't have proper watchdog now?
ramkrishna.s.vasudevan Jimmy Xiang Do you guys have any imput?

I think we should not have a very long timeout. Either we should have one that is reasonable (as in the initial patch), or go with Nicolas' suggestion of removing it completely and have simplified code.
Removing grace period.

One quick question,
Unless the META is updated asking the client to go to the new RS how is the client trying to do some operation on the region in the new RS?
So is it like the patch is trying to handle the case where the updateToMeta has happened but still not removed from the RIT on the RS side, which means there are two steps after meta update
-> Change znode to RS_ZK_OPENED
-> remove from RIT.
If the patch is addressing the following case then how does this affect the end client? So the operation will fail till the RIT on the RS side is removed.

The patch addresses the condition where RegionMovedException and slow region open causes the client to go back and forth between old and new server, hitting meta every other time.
In HBASE-7649 I also want to make timeout server-dependent, so going to new server earlier will be more prevalent.

HRegionCacheLocation just has seqid in it now. Is that enough to justify separate class? If you left it in RegionLocation, your patch would be a good bit smaller again (smile).

Is the class comment on RegionOpeningException right? Is it copy/paste?

Higher-level, patch looks good (the intent that is).

Also, higher-level again, agree w/ Nicolas Liochon philosophy of lets remove the papering over of issues – in this case the timeout on cache (as has been done in last version of patch) – and rather reveal sooner the broke regionserver rather than hope that a trip to .META. will magically fix it all.

Good stuff Sergey.

HRegionCacheLocation just has seqid in it now. Is that enough to justify separate class? If you left it in RegionLocation, your patch would be a good bit smaller again (smile).

I think it is better decision for the future, if we want to add more information. Look at all the test code that got cleaned up because it never cared about seqid

Is the class comment on RegionOpeningException right? Is it copy/paste?

The locating-it code, yes.
rebasing patch...

Hi, any more feedback? Thanks!

I think it is better decision for the future, if we want to add more information. Look at all the test code that got cleaned up because it never cared about seqid

Could you have done same thing by having constructor that did not take a seqid? You change a good bit of core code to entertain the new subclass? I'd rather have test code bend over backward than core code?

Can you think of anything else that might go into a HRegionCacheLocation (that would make sense in a class named HRegionCacheLocation)? Otherwise, would suggest seqid go back into HRegionLocation?

What you reckon Sergey?

Well, in this case if we had a timer it could go into HRegionCacheLocation. I can remove the class, but I suspect eventually it will either be readded, or HRL will get new fields that only cache cares about... will update the patch later today.
+1 on commit. Thanks for accommodating review Sergey.
